div.p: 1. IV:15. Thursday.

These Gentlemen came as a Committee of the delegation in the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth from the towns composing the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts. Mr Thayer on their part read to me an Address and left it with me, expressing their approbation of my conduct as their Representative in Congress, especially at the last Session, and presenting me a Cane made of the timber of the frigate Constitution. I answered Mr Thayer’s address orally, and accepted the cane, as a token of their esteem the value of the Article not being of sufficient pecuniary value to be declined upon a general principle. Mr Thayer made on his account a second Address which I also answered— In the Evening, with Louisa C. Smith, Charles and his wife we visited at Mr John Greenleaf’s, and afterwards at Mrs T. B. Adams’s: both houses were full of company— Mr and Mrs Angier were at Mrs Adams’s.
2. IV. Friday.

Charles and his wife went to Boston, and returned to dine— I passed great part of the morning in the Garden, Nursery, and Seminary, but the heat was of the highest Summer temperature and I could not work. Mr Birney,
and Mr Francis Jackson were here— Having been in attendance upon a State Anti-Slavery convention this week in Boston— Mr Birney gave me a pamphlet copy of my Letters to my Constituents the Inhabitants of the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts of the 3d. 8th. 13th. and 20th. of March, and of my Speech of the 9th. of February— He said it was proposed to publish another edition of the same pamphlet— In the Evening, I visited with Charles, Mr Daniel Greenleaf, who is much indisposed with a Catarrhal cough, which he thinks the Grippe— He has been afflicted with it these five weeks, but believes himself convalescent.

3 IV. Saturday.— Finished the draught of an Oration for the next 4th. of July, at Newbury Port— Then indulged myself morning and afternoon, with visiting my plants in the Garden, Nursery and Seminary. Planted, wintered red wedge Apple seeds in a row, of the Seminary; central between two seedling peach trees and in Garden plat under the old Pear-trees— There are seedling Apples and Pears up in all my boxes and flower pots where I planted them last Summer and Autumn— Blossoms on two of my young Apple trees— No fruits yet upon any of them. Very heavy thunder shower this Evening which kept us up till Midnight.
4. IV:30. Sunday

I read my Oration for the 4th. of July to ascertain how long it would take in the delivery. It took two hours and 7. minutes to read— Heard Mr Lunt, in the morning from John 6:53. He administered the Communion—in the afternoon from Deuteronomy 6.6.7. good moral discourses— E. Price Greenleaf, walk with me in my garden and Nursery— P. P. F. De Grand here afternoon and Evening. Walk to Charles’s House, went up to the Chambers—fine prospect— Mr. Beale and his daughter Ann, Evening here. Read the 11th. Sermon of the 9th. Volume of Saurin— Upon the cause of the loss or ruin of Sinners— All imputed to themselves.
5. IV. Monday

Mr Mace Smith and his Son Horace came out from Boston to see me— He requested me to recommend his Son for admission next year as a Cadet at West-Point— He had two certificates from Boston Schools in his favour and one from D. Webster and his partner Kinsman— Midshipman John Q. Adams was here; and after dinner I had a long visit from Whittier and Garrison— Much time wasted in my Garden—Nursery, and Seminary— Headed down the half-dead Black Jack Oak— Call at Mr Brigham’s shop, and at the Quincy Patriot printing-Office— J A. Green, not there— Wrote to my wife— Evening walk with Louisa C. Smith, Charles and his wife to visit Mr and Mrs Lunt—
6. IV. Tuesday.

Charles went with Midshipman John Q. Adams to Boston, and returned to dinner— I am falling into a waste of time which I fear I have not strength of mind to resist— Much of the day was spent in examining my plants, and inspecting the Garden, Nursery and Seminary. Visited also my Orchard in which there is much to do— The two Misses Grimke of South-Carolina, with Mr and Mrs Fuller, and had much argumentative conversation with me upon Slavery and abolition. And after dinner Revd. Mr Lothrop, minister of the Brattle Street Church in Boston, with his Son, and his relation Mr Wetmore of Utica N.Y. just returned, from a Southern and Western tour— Letter from Minott Thayer.
7. IV:15. Wednesday.

My visits to my Garden, Nursery and Seminary are idle— The suspicion that the Elm may be propagated by slips surprizes me, and I observe to ascertain the fact. Met in the garden this morning the father of my Tenant John J. Carr from Loudon, New-Hampshire, the next Town to Concord; he drives Cattle to Brighton for sale— Conversation with him upon Politics— Mrs Mary Jane Lawrence, of Cohassett, came to apply for a widow’s Pension— I promised to write to the Secretary of War— E Price Greenleaf here this afternoon for Spanish Books— Answered Letter from J. G. Harris— New-Bedford— Weather fair and cool.

8. IV. Thursday. Charles went to Boston and returned to dinner— Cool East wind— Wrote to my wife—took the Letter to the Post-Office— Call twice at the printing Office of the Quincy Patriot, but J. A. Greenleaf the publisher was not there— Visit to Mr Edward Miller, and delivered to his daughter Hannah S. a Letter to her received this morning from Elizabeth C. Adams Took up a seedling Lime tree growing under a tree in the Hancock lot and set it out in my Seminary— Still idle.
9. IV. Friday

Mr Greene the Publisher of the Quincy Patriot was here this morning— I asked him to collect the numbers of his Paper containing my Letters to the Abolition Petitioners from the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, which he promised to do. Mr Beale and his daughter Ann were here this Evening— I wrote Letters this morning to Minott Thayer, to John Otis, to Joel R. Poinsett, Secretary of War, and to Levi Woodbury Secretary of the Treasury; but my waste of time in my Garden, Nursery and Seminary mortifies me without producing reformation. Drizzling Showers.

10. III:45 Saturday— Wrote this morning to my wife. Then rode with Charles to Boston— Left a card at Mr John D. Williams’s, visited at Governor E. Everett’s, at Mr James H. Foster’s where I saw Mrs Foster, Louisa and Mary, and at Mrs Dexter’s— Met Edmund Quincy. Then called at Charles’s Office and rode with him to Medford. Visit at Mr John Angier’s—he was gone to Boston— Saw Mrs Angier— Then went and dined with Mr Peter C. Brooks— Meeting of the trustees of the Agricultural Society there— Loammi Baldwin, Edward Brooks, Peter C. Brooks junr Henry Codman, Edward Everett Benjamin Guild, John Heard, Abbott Lawrence, President Quincy and his Son Josiah, Caleb Stetson, Judge Story, Mr Wadsworth, John Wells, and T. L. Winthrop were there— In the Evening we returned through Boston to Quincy. Sidney Brooks arrived yesterday at New-York returned from Europe— Cold and comfortless day— Dry Northeasterly storm with occasional drizzling mist.— John C. Gray and Henderson Inches
11. V. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt from 1. Kings 19.12. “And after the fire, a still small voice”— And in the afternoon from Romans 3.1. “What advantage then hath the Jew! or what profit is there of circumcision? 2. Much, every way: chiefly because that unto them were committed the Oracles of God”— I read the 12th. and last Sermon of the 9th Volume of Saurin; and finished a Letter to Mr De Tocqueville. We had sundry visitors in the early part of the Evening, and Francis Frothingham who had come out from Boston with Mr Wayles dined with us.
12. IV: Monday

Mr William Goodell of Utica, New-York, editor of a Newspaper called, the Friend of Man, brought me a Letter of Introduction from John G. Whittier, and had about two hours of conversation with me; chiefly upon the subjects of Slavery and abolition— I wrote a short Letter to the Baron Charles Dupin, who had sent me an introductory lecture, to a course upon Geometry applied to the Arts, which he delivered on the 27th of November last at Paris— My visits to my Garden, Nursery and Seminary were barren—but I finished planting my wintered Apple and Pear Seeds, and dried cherries.
13. IV Tuesday

All I did this day was to write a short Letter to my wife, which I took to the Post Office, and on returning I cut out a piece of the sod, under the Hancock lot lime-tree which I set out in the Seminary nearly under my writing chamber window. I planted also 10 wintered red-wedge Apple seeds in the garden close to the orchard fence, between 2 Chance-planted seedling peach-trees— My Son’s wife and Louisa C. Smith went and took tea at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Charles and I went afterwards for them, and walked home with them— I cannot account for the waste of time—
14: IV:30. Wednesday

Charles and his wife went to Boston this morning, and returned to dinner. They saw Mrs Sidney Brooks; just returned with her husband from a three years tour in Europe— The midshipman John Quincy was here this morning— A man by the name of Daniel Hooker from Goshen Vermont was here to enquire about the right of collateral relations to bounty Lands for revolutionary Soldier services— He said his uncle John Hooker, enlisted for the War in 1777. in the Connecticut line— And he shewed me a Letter from W. Gordon of the War Department to Horace Everett dated in February last, stating that the name of John Hooker was transferred in 1781 to the invalid regiment; that it did not appear that he had served till the close of the revolutionary war, and was therefore not entitled to bounty Lands. Mr Daniel Hooker said that in 1810 his father had given a power of Attorney to another man named Hooker to procure a Patent for the land to which his brothers service had been entitled; that Hooker the Attorney had said that the land was located, but he knew not what had become of him. That Mr Slade had promised to make enquiries for himself the Commissioner of the general Land Office, but acknowledged to him that he had not done it— He was dissatisfied with Everett and Slade; said that in his town, they were friends of Liberty and talked of the Government’s cheating people out of their property— I answered him sharply on this observation, and told him that by his own Story, if he had been cheated out of his property it was not by the Government— But I said if he wished me to make enquiries for him at the Land Office I would do so and write to him the result which he said he would thank me to do. He thanked me also for making the offer— The Revd Mr May read and delivered to me two Resolutions of the Inhabitants of the town of Scituate on the 1st. of May last, approving of my conduct at the last Session of Congress, and censuring the disregard
by Congress of the right of Petition— I had a long conversation with Mr May, who is a zealous abolitionist.— In the Evening, with Charles I visited Mr Whitney the Minister.
15. III:45. Thursday—

The Midshipman was here this morning— His brother Joseph did not offer himself for examination at Baltimore. I wrote to my wife, and took the Letter with one to Mr Bovee late a Member of Congress from the State of New-York, to the Post-Office. Began the revised draught of an Oration for the 4th. of July to be delivered (if possible) at Newbury-Port— I visit daily my Garden, Nursery and Seminary— French the gardener, broke with a stroke of the Scythe my Pot 19. in which were 37. Dexter Apple-seedlings, and Galene Pears, the seeds of which I had sown the 30th. of last September, which had come up, and were flourishing— He transplanted them, this day to the Garden in a row near the old St. Germain Pear tree: and to finish the row I planted 5 flushing Plum Stones, wintered, but which sink in water— I have also transplanted Seedling Lime trees from under the Hancock lot tree one to the Seminary under the eastern end of the House, and another to the Garden— Light sprinkling of rain, but not enough to promote vegetation.
16. III.45— Friday

William Spear here— Pew N. 75 to be conveyed by deed to Job. Faxon— I make the second draught of my oration a daily task, not to be neglected— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— My Diary runs into irretrievable arrears— Garden—Nursery—Seminary morning and afternoon— New plant-pot N. 19. Old Philadelphia Ash-seeds—planted in it— Threatened shower cold and cloudy day— Evening visit with Charles and the Ladies to Mr T. Greenleaf’s.
17. III.45. Saturday.

Copious rain in the Night and this morning— Cold North-easterly Storm all day— I went to the printing Office of the Quincy Patriot, and Mr. Green gave me the papers of Jany 28. Feby 4. 11. 18. 25 March 4. 18. 25. April 1. 15. containing all my publications in that Journal, relating to the proceedings in the late House of
Representatives of the United States, on the abolition Petitions— Mr Stephen C. Phillips of Salem, has written to me to ask the loan of the file of them. I asked Mr Green to publish my Speech of 9. February which he promised to do—and also the two pension acts of 4. July 1836 and 3. March 1837. and the regulations of the War Department for carrying them into execution— Returning home, I took up a seedling lime tree, under the tree in the Hancock lot, and set it out in my garden
18. IV. Sunday.

Heard Dr Kendall of Plymouth, this morning from 2. Peter 1.16. [“]For we have not followed cunningly devised fables, when we made known unto you, the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ, but were eye witnesses of his majesty” The transfiguration upon the mount a solemn subject— The afternoon Sermon was from Psalm 72.6. “He shall come down, like rain upon the mown grass; as showers that water the Earth.” There was nothing remarkable in either of these discourses, both of which were sensible and pious— Dr Kendall dined with us; and just before dinner my wife with Mary and her two children came in from Washington, which they left last Thursday with the afternoon Cars— Elizabeth C. Adams and the Midshipman Joseph H were with them—Thomas Nelson the Coachman—Rachel andGoods— They came yesterday morning from Philadelphia; and arrived at 8 this Morning at Providence— Midshipman John Quincy was here this afternoon. In the Evening I walked with Charles to Coll. Quincy’s and we spent the Evening there— Mrs. Quincy’s aunt Mrs Speakman was there— Conversation with Mrs Quincy upon unitarianism and the Logos— I read this afternoon the first Sermon of the tenth volume of Saurin, on the evil consequences of a bad education—upon the character and story of Eli and his Sons— This part of the collection is posthumous, and this Sermon upon bad education did not please me.
19. IV. Monday.

Charles went into Boston and returned to dinner. The day fine and very warm; but in my visits to my Garden, Nursery and Seminary I made no new observation—except of the mutilated plumelets of two, of the four chance planted Seedling Pear trees close to the Western Althaea before my Eastern front door— The vegetation of the Elm slip will come to nothing— Mary’s two children Mary Louisa, and Georgiana Frances began anew their Bible reading to me with the first four chapters of the book of Joshua— Idled away the afternoon only reading a few pages of Tocqueville upon our American democracy.
20. IV. Tuesday.

I had sent invitations to Mr P. C. Brooks and his Son of the same name, and to Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks to come and dine with us, which they had promised unless the weather should prevent—but there was a heavy rain all the morning, and they did not come— After dinner, I called three times at the Office of the Quincy Patriot and at last saw Mr Green— I left with him a short editorial Article to be published next Saturday with the Pension Acts of 4. July 1836. and 3. March 1837. and the regulations of the War Department for carrying them into execution— Also a printed circular with Resolutions of the American Institute at New-York inviting an internal industry Convention to meet at Philadelphia next August—to be published when convenient— I left also a copy of the Cincinnati Edition of my poem of Dermott MacMorrogh, which Mr Green had requested— I took and left with the Revd. Mr Lunt the two Dissertations written by members of the senior-Sophister Class, for the Bowdoin prizes of 40 and 30 dollars, upon which President Quincy has invited him with my Son Charles and me to judge— I called at Mrs. T. B. Adams’s—and left a Letter to her from her Son Isaac Hull which I had received this morning— Returning home I took up under the Lime-tree in the Hancock lot, a seedling lime which I transplanted to my garden— I found at home that my dear wife had gone to bed sick, with a return of Erisypelas— John Quincy Adams 2. and
Mrs Phineas Foster’s son William were here this Evening— Mr Peter Whitney had called this morning to enquire how I intended to go to Roxbury to-morrow— He had nominated me last Sunday at a Church meeting after the afternoon service to go as a delegate to the ordination of Mr Theodore Parker, as Minister of the second Congregational Church at Roxbury, the same where George Whitney was ordained June 1833— I said I intended to take a Horse and Chaise and ride over— I accordingly engaged one of Gillet
21. IV.15. Wednesday.

Mr Duggan is this year the Collector of the town and County tax, for which he brought my bill.— I had ordered the horse and chaise of Gillet to come at 1/2 past 12. at Noon—he came first at 1/2 past 9 and then at 1— I took Thomas Nelson the Coachman with me and rode to Roxbury; but missed the way went round by Jamaica Plains, rode about two miles beyond the Meeting house, and upon discovering the blunder by enquiring of a boy, returned and on coming in sight of Taft’s tavern met the members of the Council going to the Meeting house. I alighted; sent Thomas with the horse and chaise to the tavern and walked with Professor Ware the father Dr Pearce of Brookline and Mr Convers Francis the preacher of the day— The procession was formed at the school house, near the meeting house, and I walked with it.— The services were 1. Anthem. 2. Introductory prayer by Mr Robbins. 3 Selections from Scripture read by Dr Gray 4 Original hymn by John S. Dwight. 5. Sermon by Mr Convers Francis 6. Sentence sung by the Choir 7. Ordaining prayer by Professor Henry Ware junr. 8. Charge by Mr Stetson. 9. Right hand of fellowship by Mr Ripley. 10. Hymn by Mr Pierpont 11. Address to the Society by Mr George Whitney. 12. Concluding prayer by Mr Cunningham 13. Anthem 14. Benediction, by Mr Theodore Parker, the Minister now ordained— The ceremonies began precisely at 3. O’Clock and finished about 10 minutes past six— At the invitation of the Parish Committee by Dr Gray the Company then returned to Taft’s
where there was a supper of tea and coffee with cold meats—Pies, and fruits, among which a few sour Strawberries, not half ripe— I came home; following Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt, in their Carryall: and lost my Umbrella out of the Chaise— Elizabeth C. Adams was at our house, and the Chaise took her home— Immediately after I reached home came on a heavy rain.
22. IV:30. Thursday.

Rain all night and all this morning. My excursion to Dedham yesterday occasioned some interruption of my work, which kept me closer at it much of this day— The midshipman John Q was here this morning— I was intensely occupied with the revisal of my draught and had time for nothing else—the Garden, Nursery and Seminary, presenting nothing to invite my attendance— I neglected my diary, but advanced six pages in my revisal— My wife continues quite ill; confined to her bed.
23. IV:15. Friday.

The rain has ceased but the sky is yet cloudy and the weather chilling and gloomy. Mr and Mrs Lunt paid an afternoon visit here. Mr Lunt borrowed Kaimes’s Elements of Criticism— He has read the two Dissertations by Junior Sophisters at Cambridge written for the Bowdoin prizes, and upon which he, with my Son and myself are to be the judges, and he thinks neither of them has much merit.— I received a Letter from Mr Caleb Cushing at Newbury Port, inviting me to his house on the 4th. of July—and a Letter from W. W. Lee, for a Committee of the young men of Springfield inviting me to join them in the celebration of the day there.
24. IV: Saturday.

Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I received a Letter from the Secretary of War, with two Reports from J. L. Edwards the Commissioner of Pension’s, adverse to the claim of Mary Jane Lawrence and also to the claim of the children of Coll. Partridge— Mr Fuller called upon me this afternoon, and left with me the first Volume of Miss Martineau’s Society in America and two numbers of the

Boston Atlas one of them containing an Article upon Texas; and the other the Address of Mr Minott Thayer to me and my answer— Miss Martineau’s book took hold of me so that the afternoon was gone before I reflected that I had something else to do— I had an afternoon visit from President Quincy; who was returning to Cambridge having come out and dined with his Son. Catherinewent this Morning for Portsmouth.
25. IV. Sunday

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Matthew 23.30. [“]For in the resurrection, they neither marry nor are given in marriage; but are as the angels of God in heaven.”—and in the afternoon from Romans 4:18. “Who against hope, believed in hope.” The first of these Discourses was on the probable condition of our existence in the world to come— The second upon hope arising from despair, both, very interesting Sermons—but of the condition of our existence in a future state, we are so destitute excepting from what we find in the new Testament, that we can form no conception of it. Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and dined and spent the day with us— I read the second Sermon of the tenth Volume of Saurin upon the Communion of Easter.
26. IV. Monday.

Peter Turner came this morning, wanting to borrow 100 dollars which I was not able to lend him— There was an Association meeting of Ministers at Mr Lunt’s this afternoon, which brought me several visitors Dr Gray and Mr George Whitney this forenoon Dr Parkman, Dr Frothingham and Mr Lothrop after dinner— Mrs Gorham and her Son in Law, Mr Robbins were also here to visit Mrs Charles Adams, and Midshipman Joseph H, with his Sister Elizabeth— Miss Miller and Fanny Foster were here at tea— The revisal of my Oration absorbs my time to the exclusion of all other occupation
27. IV. Tuesday.

Mrs Jacob Carr, formerly Catherine Goods, who was married here by Mr Lunt last October, has a son born at 2. O’Clock this morning.— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine.— Dr Woodward was here and Mrs Miller and Miss Susan Quincy. I finished my revised draught of an Oration for the 4th. of July. but was so unwell all the afternoon and evening that I was entirely disabled for reading or writing.— The burden was more upon my Spirits than upon any thing else— I have fallen so far short of my conceptions and my wishes— I received a Letter from E. Cruft inviting me to join the President and Directors of the Atlas Insurance company, for a fishing excursion below the Light House next Thursday.
28. IV:15 Wednesday

I received and answered a Letter from Mr D. J. Pearce of Newport Rhode-Island; and I answered also a Letter from Mr W. W. Lee of Springfield inviting me to join a celebration of the Anniversary of Independence by the young men of that Town— Mrs Maxim was here, now living at Abington.— She is the daughter of Joseph Nightengale of this town, who she says served as a Soldier the whole of the Revolutionary War— He died more than 25 years since, and she said she had heard that his children would be entitled to receive a Pension for his services— I read to her the Pension Acts of 1836. and 1837, and the regulations of the War Department for their execution— She could not readily understand what difference it made whether her father died before or after 1831. so as to affect the right of his children to a pension for his revolutionary Services— Mr Lunt was also there this afternoon. On consultation with him and my Son, we agreed to award the second Bowdoin prize of 30 dollars to the Dissertation upon the Prospects of the Roman Catholic Church in this Country; and none to the other dissertation, upon the moral responsibility of the free expression of dangerous, important opinions—
29. IV. Thursday

I went into Boston this morning with Thomas Nelson, with a horse and chaise hired of Gillet— At 8 O’Clock I called at Mr. Edward Cruft’s, went with him to the central wharf, and there embarked in a Yarmouth Packet and went on a Fishing party outside of Boston harbour—Samuel A. Welles George Bethune, Peleg Sprague—Phineas Sprague,—Commodore Downes—Mr Walker the Minister of Charlestown, Mr Harris, Mr Devens, a Mr Walsh, and one or two others with Mr Cruft and his Son Edward formed the party— We went as has almost always happened to me in all these parties, first drifting slowly down the harbour with a calm then beating out against an Easterly breeze Then trying successively four or five equally bad fishing grounds and finally beating back with a Southwestern breeze— We caught three Codfish and about 30 haddock, of which I took seven, and lost one cod, between the Water and the boat— We had a cold collation at Noon—a dinner of Chowder and fried fish at 4. P.M and Coffee, and tin sealed Bourgogne Mousseux afterwards— We landed Commodore Downes and the Charlestown Gentlemen, in a boat near the Navy-Yard and alighted, between India and central wharves at 7. in the Evening— I called, at Mr Joseph W. Jenkins’s shop— Merchant-tailor, opposite the central South door of the old town-house, and bespoke a black silk waistcoat, and from Isaac Foster’s livery-stable in Devonshire Street, rode home to Quincy in one hour— Mr Beale and his daughter Ann were spending the Evening at our house
30. V:30. Friday

I received yesterday morning a Letter from Caleb Cushing of Newbury-Port a Letter from W. Plumer junr of Epping New-Hampshire, and two printed Circular Letters from Governor Edward Everett, with copies of Resolutions adopted last Spring by the Legislature of the Commonwealth— I was this day so much over-wearied
with the heating of yesterdays party, that I was obliged to confine myself almost entirely to the house.— It was a thorough Summers day. Charles and his wife went to Boston and returned to dine— I was endeavouring with partial success to abridge my Oration for next Tuesday.— Disabled with languor, and scarcely able to stroll about the garden— Discovered a Peach-tree coming up in Louisa Catherine’s plantation—and Oaks and hickories just beginning to shew themselves— All I could accomplish was to answer the Letter of Mr Pietro Alessandro, which he sent me with his Italian poem of Monte Auburno.

Day. Rise between 4 and 5. O’Clock— See the Sunrise when it rises clean which has not happened these ten days— Water my Plants write, to finish my Oration; which is now finished— Breakfast at 8— Stroll in the garden Nursery and Seminary till noon—doing nothing but look at my seedling trees— Read Newspapers and Letters, and write till 2. or half-past two—dine— Throw myself in the bed, for an hour or two after dinner—read or write for a couple of hours between 4 and 7. Tea and thickened milk evening in conversation with my family— Much time wasted.
